meanings.definition: Bribe or otherwise induce (someone) to commit an unlawful act.
meanings.sent1: The corrupt official tried to suborn the witness into lying in court.
meanings.sent2: She was arrested for attempting to suborn a police officer to ignore the crime.
meanings.sent3: The shady businessman's plan to suborn the judge backfired when he got caught.
meanings.sent4: The criminal mastermind used his wealth to suborn the jury and secure his acquittal.
meanings.sent5: The evil queen's advisor would often suborn the guards to carry out her wicked schemes.

meanings.definition: Persuade (someone) to do something illegal or wrong.
meanings.sent1: He tried to suborn his friend into stealing from the store.
meanings.sent2: The con artist managed to suborn the unsuspecting victim into signing a fraudulent contract.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous student attempted to suborn his classmates into skipping class.
meanings.sent4: The cunning villain used his charm to suborn the hero into betraying his allies.
meanings.sent5: The persuasive cult leader would suborn his followers into committing heinous acts in his name.

meanings.definition: To induce (a person) to commit perjury.
meanings.sent1: The lawyer was accused of trying to suborn the witness to lie under oath.
meanings.sent2: The defendant's attempt to suborn the key witness was uncovered during the trial.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked about trying to suborn his friend into lying about their whereabouts.
meanings.sent4: The politician's campaign manager was caught trying to suborn a witness to change their testimony.
meanings.sent5: The manipulative actress would suborn her co-stars to support her false alibi.
